spoil.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to have a bad effect on something so that it is no longer attractive, enjoyable, useful etc
spoil.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The whole park is spoiled by litter.
We didn’t let the incident spoil our day.
I don’t want to spoil your fun.
Why do you always have to spoil everything?
spoil.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to give a child everything they want, or let them do whatever they want, often with the result that they behave badly
spoil.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: She’s an only child, but they didn’t really spoil her.
His mother and sisters spoil him rotten (=spoil him very much).
spoil.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to look after someone in a way that is very kind or too kind
spoil.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: You’ll have to let me spoil you on your birthday.
Go on, spoil yourself. Have another piece of cake.
spoil.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Food will spoil if the temperature in your freezer rises above 8°C.
spoil.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to mark a ballot paper wrongly so that your vote is not included
spoil.translation[0].note_box[0].section: spoil
to have a bad effect on something so that it is much less attractive, enjoyable etc
New housing developments are spoiling the countryside.
The bad weather completely spoiled our holiday.
ruin
to spoil something completely and permanently
Using harsh soap to wash your face can ruin your skin.
The argument ruined the evening for me.
mar
to spoil something by making it less attractive or enjoyable
His handsome Arab features were marred by a long scar across his face.
Outbreaks of fighting marred the New Year celebrations.
detract from something
to slightly spoil something that is generally very good, beautiful, or impressive
The huge number of tourists rather detracts from the city’s appeal.
There were a few minor irritations, but this did not detract from our enjoyment of the holiday.
undermine
to spoil something that you have been trying to achieve
The bombings undermined several months of careful negotiations.
sour
to spoil a friendly relationship between people or countries
The affair has soured relations between the UK and Russia.
poison
to spoil a close relationship completely, so that people can no longer trust each other
Their marriage was poisoned by a terrible dark secret.
mess something up
to spoil something important or something that has been carefully planned
If there’s any delay, it will mess up our whole schedule.
spoil.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: waste material such as earth and stones from a mine or hole in the ground
